questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 4-month history of reddening of the nose and cheeks. She has no itching or pain. She first noticed the redness while on a recent holiday in Spain, where she stayed at the beach and did daily wine tastings. She has tried several brands of sunscreen, stopped going outside in the middle of the day, and has not drunk alcohol since her trip, but the facial redness persists. The patient reports that she has had a lot of stress lately due to relationship problems with her husband. She has no history of serious illness. Her younger sister has acne vulgaris, and her mother has systemic lupus erythematosus. She does not smoke. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows erythema of the nose, chin, and medial cheeks with scant papules and telangiectasias. There are no comedones or blisters. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to behavioral modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroid therapy may initially improve the erythema and telangiectasias of rosacea due to their anti-inflammatory and vasoconstrictive effects. However, corticosteroids should not be used to treat rosacea because of the risk of adverse effects of chronic corticosteroid use and rebound flares upon drug discontinuation.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzoyl peroxide is an antimicrobial agent with comedolytic properties that is mainly used to treat acne vulgaris. Acne vulgaris commonly occurs in younger individuals and is typically characterized by numerous papules, pustules, and comedones on the face, neck, shoulders, and back. This patient's age, characteristic location of lesions on the central face, and absence of comedones make rosacea the more likely diagnosis. Benzoyl peroxide is not commonly used to treat rosacea.
Image Description:

Disseminated papules, pustules, and comedones on an erythematous base are visible on the seborrheic skin of the patient's forehead.

These findings are consistent with moderate acne vulgaris.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline, tetracycline, minocycline) are used to treat severe rosacea that involves several inflammatory papules and/or pustules. Systemic therapy is not appropriate for this patient, who only has scant papules on examination and has not tried other therapies with fewer adverse effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin may be considered in patients with refractory rosacea that does not respond to other treatments. It is not used as a first-line agent due to its adverse effect profile (e.g., dry skin and mucous membranes, teratogenicity).

E) INCORRECT:

Oral hydroxychloroquine is used to treat systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) because of its anti-inflammatory and immune-modulating effects. The malar rash of SLE is characterized by erythema of the face, nose, and cheeks that worsens with sun exposure and after alcohol consumption. However, the presence of papules and telangiectasias and the absence of other common symptoms of SLE (e.g., arthritis, fatigue) make this diagnosis unlikely. This patient has rosacea, a condition for which oral hydroxychloroquine has no role in treatment.
Image Description:

Hyperpigmented areas measuring approx. 3–4 cm are visible over the patient's cheeks with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

This appearance is suggestive of a malar rash, which is typically seen in lupus erythematosus.

F) CORRECT:

Topical metronidazole has antibiotic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties and is effective in improving the erythematous and papular lesions of mild rosacea. Other effective topical therapies for mild rosacea manifesting with papules and pustules include azelaic acid (anti-inflammatory), sodium sulfacetamide (antibacterial), and ivermectin (anti-inflammatory and antiparasitic). Facial erythema and flushing can be improved with alpha-adrenergic agonists such as topical brimonidine or oxymetazoline. Therapies for severe or refractory disease include oral tetracyclines, oral isotretinoin, and laser therapy.

All patients with rosacea should be counseled to avoid triggers, which include sun exposure, hot weather, alcohol, spicy foods, and stress.
Image Description:

There is erythema, telangiectasia, papules, and pustules localized to the nose and cheeks.

These are characteristic features of rosacea.
questions.hint: This patient presents with chronic erythema of the central face with scattered papules and telangiectasias. The lesions worsened with sun exposure and after alcohol consumption. These features are characteristic of rosacea, a chronic, inflammatory skin disorder seen most commonly in middle-aged women.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of a facial rash. He occasionally feels burning or stinging over the affected area. His only medication is lisinopril. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. Which of the following most likely contributed to the development of this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutibacterium acnes (formerly known as Propionibacterium acnes) is a gram-positive bacteria species that is part of the commensal skin flora and associated with the pathogenesis of acne vulgaris. These bacteria colonize follicles and pores, digesting sebum and releasing pro-inflammatory byproducts that cause acne, which typically manifests with papules and pustules. However, this patient does not have comedones, a characteristic feature of acne vulgaris. Furthermore, acne vulgaris most commonly occurs during puberty due to an androgen-related increase in sebum production.
Image Description:

Several comedones, papules, and partially inflamed pustules are localized to the right cheek.

B) INCORRECT:

Angioedema is a well-known side effect of ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril), especially in patients with C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency. ACE inhibitor-mediated angioedema usually manifests with acute-onset swelling and erythema of the entire face. This man's rash is limited to the cheeks, nasolabial folds, and nose.
Image Description:

Facial edema, primarily affecting the eyelids, is visible on the patient's face.

C) CORRECT:

While the etiology of rosacea remains uncertain, there are several known potential triggers that precipitate or exacerbate symptoms, including stress, exercise, hot weather, sun exposure, and alcohol consumption. These triggers are believed to induce local inflammation, which causes vasodilation of cutaneous capillaries and skin flushing.
Image Description:

Papules, pustules, and erythema can be seen on the forehead, nose, and cheeks. A coarse, erythematous, and enlarged bulbous nose (rhinophyma) is also visible.

D) INCORRECT:

Filaggrin gene mutations can be found in patients with atopic dermatitis. This condition is characterized by a dry, pruritic, erythematous skin rash that begins in childhood, improves during adolescence, and becomes a chronic condition in adulthood. The location of lesions changes from the cheeks, face, and head in infants to the flexural creases (antecubital and popliteal fossae) in adults. As patients age, atopic dermatitis lesions become excoriated and lichenified. This patient's flexural surfaces are not affected and his symptoms began in adulthood, making atopic dermatitis unlikely.
Image Description:

Erythematous and scaly papules coalescing into plaques can be seen on the face of this infant.

E) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of complement component 1q (due to anti-C1q antibodies) correlates with disease activity in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The dermatologic hallmark of SLE is a butterfly rash (malar rash) that spares the nasolabial folds. This man's rash involving the nasolabial folds, in addition to pustules, is not characteristic of SLE. Also, SLE has a strong predilection for young females and often manifests with other findings, such as fevers, fatigue, myalgias, arthritis, and lupus nephritis.
Image Description:

An erythematous macular rash with adherent keratotic scaling is visible over the nasal bridge, cheek (malar eminence), brow, and chin. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold. Mild cheilitis is also visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. Because this rash typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically, resembling butterfly wings, it is also referred to as a "butterfly rash."
questions.hint: This patient presents with facial erythema, telangiectasia, papules, and pustules, which are findings characteristic of rosacea.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents with facial flushing that flares with strong emotion and hot drinks and that worsens after sun exposure. Her skin findings are shown (figure). She is otherwise healthy and has no known drug allergies.
Which one of the following systemic treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone is not indicated for the treatment of rosacea.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral methotrexate is not indicated for the treatment of rosacea.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is often used to treat other photosensitive conditions, such as cutaneous lupus erythematosus, but not rosacea.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s skin findings are typical of rosacea. The malar rash of systemic lupus erythematosus classically spares the nasolabial folds, whereas rosacea and dermatomyositis typically do not. If there is strong suspicion for collagen vascular disease (which enters into the rosacea differential diagnosis because of the persistent facial erythema) based on accompanying signs and symptoms, those conditions should be worked up on an individual basis.

Rosacea is often triggered by exposures including heat, alcohol, sunlight, hot beverages, stress, menstruation, certain medications, and certain foods. The symptoms of rosacea include facial flushing and a sense of warmth. The clinical examination reveals varying degrees of telangiectatic vessels, facial redness, and in more inflammatory variants, pink-red papulopustules. Rosacea typically develops in the fourth to sixth decade of life and has a chronic course. The diagnosis is made clinically.

Management consists of avoidance of triggers that can exacerbate the condition, patient education, and topical or systemic therapies. Options for treating the erythema include topical brimonidine, topical oxymetazoline, and laser therapy or other light-based therapies. For inflammatory lesions (papules and pustules), first-line topical therapies include topical ivermectin, topical azelaic acid, and topical metronidazole. First-line systemic treatment for moderate-to-severe inflammatory lesions is either a medication from the tetracycline class (modified-release oral doxycycline at a dose of 40 mg or oral tetracycline) or low-dose oral isotretinoin.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line systemic therapy for papulopustular rosacea is a course of tetracycline antibiotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultraviolet B phototherapy has no role in rosacea treatment.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 46-year-old woman presents with facial flushing that flares with strong emotion and hot drinks and that worsens after sun exposure. Her skin findings are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone is not indicated for the treatment of rosacea.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral methotrexate is not indicated for the treatment of rosacea.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluocinonide is not indicated for the treatment of rosacea.

D) CORRECT:

Rosacea is often triggered by exposures including heat, alcohol, sunlight, hot beverages, stress, menstruation, certain medications, and certain foods. The symptoms of rosacea include facial flushing and a sense of warmth. The clinical examination reveals varying degrees of telangiectatic vessels, facial redness, and in more inflammatory variants, pink-red papulopustules. Rosacea typically develops in the fourth to sixth decade of life and has a chronic course. The diagnosis is made clinically.

Management consists of avoidance of triggers that can exacerbate the condition, patient education, and topical or systemic therapies. Options for treating the erythema include topical brimonidine, topical oxymetazoline, and laser therapy or other light-based therapies. For inflammatory lesions (papules and pustules), first-line topical therapies include topical ivermectin, topical azelaic acid, and topical metronidazole. First-line systemic treatment for moderate-to-severe inflammatory lesions is either a medication from the tetracycline class (modified-release oral doxycycline at a dose of 40 mg or oral tetracycline) or low-dose oral isotretinoin.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line systemic therapy for papulopustular rosacea is a course of tetracycline antibiotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultraviolet B phototherapy has no role in rosacea treatment.
questions.hint: This patient’s skin findings are typical of rosacea.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic because of a facial rash. He occasionally experiences burning or stinging sensations over the affected area. A photograph of the rash is provided. Which one of the following most likely contributed to his current skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

While the etiology of rosacea remains uncertain, there are several known potential triggers that precipitate or exacerbate symptoms, including stress, exercise, hot weather, sun exposure, and alcohol consumption. These triggers are believed to induce local inflammation, which causes vasodilation of cutaneous capillaries and skin flushing.

Key learning point: Rosacea is a chronic facial skin disorder often triggered or worsened by factors such as alcohol consumption, hot weather, sun exposure, stress, and exercise.

Papules, pustules, and erythema can be seen on the forehead, nose, and cheeks. A coarse, erythematous, and enlarged bulbous nose (rhinophyma) is also visible.

Furthermore, acne vulgaris most commonly occurs during puberty due to an androgen-related increase in sebum production.

C) INCORRECT:

Microvascular immune complexes form in response to a type III hypersensitivity reaction in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The dermatologic hallmark of SLE is a butterfly rash (malar rash) that spares the nasolabial folds. This man's rash involving the nasolabial folds, in addition to pustules, is not characteristic of SLE. Also, SLE has a strong predilection for young females and often manifests with other findings, such as fevers, fatigue, myalgias, arthritis, and lupus nephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Filaggrin gene mutations can be found in patients with atopic dermatitis. As patients age, atopic dermatitis lesions become excoriated and lichenified. This patient's skin findings suggest rosacea, rather than an atopic dermatitis.

Angioedema is a well-known side effect of ACE inhibitors, especially in patients with C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency. questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of redness affecting her nose and cheeks. She first noticed the redness during a recent holiday in Spain, where she spent time at the beach and participated in daily wine tastings. She reports increased stress recently due to relationship issues with her husband. On examination, there is erythema of the nose, chin, and medial cheeks with a few papules and telangiectasias. There are no comedones or blisters. The remainder of the examination is normal. In addition to behavioral modifications, which one of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral hydroxychloroquine is used to treat systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) because of its antiinflammatory and immune-modulating effects. The malar rash of SLE is characterized by erythema of the face, nose, and cheeks that worsens with sun exposure and after alcohol consumption. However, the presence of papules and telangiectasias and the absence of other common symptoms of SLE (e.g., arthritis, fatigue) make this diagnosis unlikely. This patient has rosacea, a condition for which oral hydroxychloroquine has no role in treatment.

B) CORRECT:

Topical metronidazole has antibiotic, antiinflammatory, and antioxidant properties and is effective in improving the erythematous and papular lesions of mild rosacea. Other effective topical therapies for mild rosacea manifesting with papules and pustules include azelaic acid (antiinflammatory), sodium sulfacetamide (antibacterial), and ivermectin (antiinflammatory and antiparasitic). Facial erythema and flushing can be improved with alpha-adrenergic agonists such as topical brimonidine or oxymetazoline. Therapies for severe or refractory disease include oral tetracyclines, oral isotretinoin, and laser therapy.

All patients with rosacea should be counseled to avoid triggers, which include sun exposure, hot weather, alcohol, spicy foods, and stress.

Key learning point: Topical metronidazole is the first-line treatment for mild papulopustular rosacea, along with avoidance of known triggers such as sun, alcohol, and stress.
Image Description:

There is erythema, telangiectasia, papules, and pustules localized to the nose and cheeks.

These are characteristic features of rosacea.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin may be considered in patients with refractory rosacea that does not respond to other treatments. It is not used as a first-line agent due to its adverse effect profile (e.g., dry skin and mucous membranes, teratogenicity).

D) INCORRECT:

Benzoyl peroxide is an antimicrobial agent with comedolytic properties that is mainly used to treat acne vulgaris. Acne vulgaris commonly occurs in younger individuals and is typically characterized by numerous papules, pustules, and comedones on the face, neck, shoulders, and back. This patient's age, characteristic location of lesions on the central face, and absence of comedones make rosacea the more likely diagnosis. Benzoyl peroxide is not commonly used to treat rosacea.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline, tetracycline, minocycline) are used to treat severe rosacea that involves several inflammatory papules and/or pustules. Systemic therapy is not appropriate for this patient, who only has scant papules on examination and has not tried other therapies with fewer adverse effects.
questions.hint: This patient presents with chronic erythema of the central face with scattered papules and telangiectasias. The lesions worsened with sun exposure and after alcohol consumption. These features are characteristic of rosacea, a chronic, inflammatory skin disorder seen most commonly in middle-aged women.
